questions.prompt: The time constant of an RC circuit with R=2kΩ and C=5μF is:
questions.explanation: τ = RC = 2000 × 5×10⁻⁶ = 0.01 s = 10 ms. This means 63.2% of the transition completes in 10 ms.

questions.prompt: The time constant of an RL circuit with R=100Ω and L=50mH is:
questions.explanation: τ = L/R = 50×10⁻³/100 = 5×10⁻⁴ s = 0.5 ms. Note: for RL, τ = L/R (not R·L).

questions.prompt: To find x(∞) in a DC circuit, you replace C with:
options: Short circuit and L with open
Open circuit and L with short
questions.correctAnswer: Open circuit and L with short
questions.explanation: At DC steady state: capacitor current = 0 (open circuit), inductor voltage = 0 (short circuit). This gives a purely resistive circuit to solve for x(∞).

questions.prompt: In the three-step inspection method, the three quantities are:
questions.explanation: x(t₀) = initial value (from continuity), x(∞) = steady state (from DC analysis), τ = time constant (R_TH·C or L/R_TH). These three numbers completely determine the exponential response.

questions.prompt: An RC circuit has v_C(0) = 5V, v_oc = 12V, τ = 3ms. What is v_C(3ms)?
The duality between RC and RL circuits means:
options: They produce the same waveform swap v↔i, RC↔L/R
RL circuits have no exponential response
questions.correctAnswer: They produce the same waveform swap v↔i, RC↔L/R
questions.explanation: v_C in RC ↔ i_L in RL, τ=RC ↔ τ=L/R. The formula x(t) = x(∞)+[x(0)−x(∞)]e^(−t/τ) works for both with appropriate substitutions.

questions.prompt: R_TH in the time constant formula is the Thevenin resistance:
options: Seen by the capacitor/inductor with all independent sources turned off
questions.correctAnswer: Seen by the capacitor/inductor with all independent sources turned off
questions.explanation: Turn off all independent sources (voltage→short, current→open) and find the resistance looking into the terminals where C or L is connected. This is R_TH for the time constant calculation.

questions.prompt: A discharging RC circuit has v_C(0) = 10V and v_oc = 0V. The solution is:
questions.explanation: x(∞) = 0, x(0) = 10. So v_C = 0 + (10−0)e^(−t/τ) = 10e^(−t/τ). Pure exponential decay from 10V to 0V.
